subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA and JAPANESE STOCK NEWS: ACCC will not oppose Elders (ELD AT) acquisition of Australian Independent Rural Retailers, Yahoo Japan (4689 JT) is to acquire a 50.1% stake in Zozo (3092 JT); South Korea is closed for holiday
content:
AUSTRALIA

ANZ Bank (ANZ AT) - Co. is reportedly still interested in selling its UDC business. (Newswires)

Elders (ELD AT) - ACCC will not oppose Co. acquisition of Australian Independent Rural Retailers. (Newswires)

Ramelius Resources (RMS AT) - Co. Vivien mine life was extended to at least end of FY21. (Newswires)

Sigma Pharmaceuticals (SIG AT) - Australian Pharma (API AT) is thought to still be interested in the Co. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT) - Co. is thought to be seeking to offload its AUD 600mln equipment loans book, while Co. CFO King is to retire next year. (Newswires/The Australian)

Woolworths (WOW AT) - Co. unit Endeavour Drinks acquired McLaren Vale winery Chapel Hill. (Newswires)

Financials - ASIC is reportedly conducting a total of 86 probes into Australia’s big four banks and AMP (AMP AT). (SMH)

 

JAPAN

Dai Nippon Printing (7912 JT) - Co. will repurchase as much as 9.94% of shares for JPY 60bln. (Newswires)

Fanuc (6954 JT) - Co. will begin machine tool cloud service with Fujitsu. (Nikkei)

Idemitsu Kosan (5019 JT) - Co. unit is to acquire 100MW solar project Pioneer in Colorado. (Newswires)

Japan Post Insurance (7181 JT) - Japan’s FSA has begun on-site investigation which is expected to take 2 months before issuing conclusions. (Newswires)

Zozo (3092 JT) - Yahoo Japan (4689 JT) is to acquire a 50.1% stake in the Co. (Newswires)

Mexico President Lopez Obrador says had a good phone call with US President Trump in which they reaffirmed willingness to maintain friendly and cooperative relations
US President Trump has ruled out unilaterally indexing capital gains tax to inflation, according to the White House
Taiwan to buy USD 3.6bln of agricultural goods from US to bolster US in trade war, according to SCMP
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include New Zealand Food Prices, Japanese Machine Orders and PPI
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China released a tariff exemption list for products from the US effective on September 17th in which the items on the list will not be subject to additional tariffs imposed by China on US goods as countermeasures to trade action taken by the US. Exemptions include food products and lubricants although does not list corn, soybeans or pork, while China will also consider tariff exemptions for additional products from the US. (Xinhua)

US President Trump said that China made a "good gesture" with the latest tariff exclusions, while he quoted tweets about China’s tariff suspension which suggested China was being hit very hard with supply chains breaking up as many companies move, or look to move to other countries and that it was much more expensive to China than originally thought. (Newswires/Twitter)

Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said to the US delegation in Beijing that he believes they have the wisdom to find a solution acceptable to both. (Fox Business News)

China’s Former Leading Agriculture Negotiator Guoqiang stated that China should continue to use purchases of US farm products as a "countermeasure" in US trade talks, while he added China should avoid over dependence on imports and rely mainly on domestic supplies to meet demand. (SCMP)

China is tipped to start its rate cutting road map as early as next week as an economic slowdown deepens, according to press reports citing analysts. (SCMP)

Senior Chinese diplomat said China cannot be deterred in anti-poverty efforts and long-term growth strategy even amid trade talks, while the diplomat suggested China won’t make any compromise even on promising to eliminate IP theft as it would stall growth. (Fox)

China permitted imports of soymeal from Argentina for the first time as it seeks to expand its import channels for farm products amid ongoing US-China trade war. (Global Times)

China Ambassador to Germany said there is sufficient proof that foreign forces intervened in Hong Kong and that the reception of Hong Kong activist Wong in Berlin has sent a very negative signal for bilateral relations. (Newswires)

  • Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Aug) 1210B vs. Exp. 1200B (Prev. 1060B). (Newswires) 
  • Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Aug) 1980B vs. Exp. 1605B (Prev. 1010B) 
  • Chinese M2 Money Supply (Aug) Y/Y 8.2% vs. Exp. 8.1% (Prev. 8.1%) 

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said the UK can manage very well without a Brexit deal and that he wants a high wage, low tax economy, while he reiterated his stance that the backstop is going to be removed and they will not accept a Northern Ireland backstop, but they will work for a Brexit deal and that great progress is being made. (Newswires)

UK Government said it will not publish internal messages sent about the prorogation of Parliament, despite being forced to following a vote by MPs and stated the request is "unprecedented, inappropriate and disproportionate". Furthermore, UK Operation Yellowhammer (government's reasonable worst case Brexit scenario) papers have been released which discussed public and business readiness will be at a low level and that the EU would not be nearly as badly affected as the UK, although Business Minister Leadsom is sticking with the UK government and will not publish the full details of its Operation Yellowhammer No Deal contingency planning despite being ordered to by MPs. (Newswires)

Scottish Court ruled that UK PM Johnson's decision to suspend Parliament is unlawful and as a result, the case will now likely go to the UK Supreme Court, while it was also reported that no order has been given to cancel the prorogation ahead of that hearing which will commence on Tuesday. (Newswires/BBC/Twitter)

ECB sources stated the ECB is to cut some growth projections with both 2019 and 2020 GDP expansion seen not far above 1%, while the bank’s projections on headline and underlying inflation is to show slow protracted rise in the coming years. Furthermore, the sources stated that forecasts suggest even with a new round of stimulus, the ECB will struggle to hit its inflation target which it has failed to do since 2013. (Newswires)

Dutch Parliament passed a motion opposing tiered rates for banks and has sent a letter to ECB's Draghi. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e -6.912M vs. Exp. -2.686M (Prev. -4.771M). (Newswires)

OPEC Monthly Report showed 2019 oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.02mln BPD; down 80k BPD from the prior report and that 2020 world oil demand is forecast to increase 1.08mln BPD Y/Y (vs. Prev. 1.14mln BPD). OPEC said the cut in global oil demand growth forecast can be attributed to weaker-than-expected H1 2019 data from various global demand centres and slower 2019 economic growth projections. Furthermore, preliminary data indicated that global oil supply in August rose 830k BPD to average 99.24mln BPD and OPEC crude production in August rose 136k BPD to average 29.74mln BPD according to secondary sources, while crude oil output increased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, Iraq and the UAE, while production in Venezuela, Iran, Libya, Kuwait and Algeria declined. (Newswires)

OPEC countries reportedly fulfilled the OPEC+ deal by a rate of 131% and non-OPEC countries fulfilled it by a rate 147% in August, according to sources. (Tass)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said there are no plans to discuss deeper production cuts at the JMMC but mentioned that the slowing global demand for oil will be a discussion. (Newswires)

Oman's Oil Minister said there is an appetite among OPEC+ members for more production cuts if necessary. (Argus/Twitter)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US preparations are underway for a possible US President Trump and Iranian President Rouhani meeting on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, according to sources. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he is not looking at anything when asked if he would meet Iranian President Rouhani and replied we will see what happens when questioned if he would ease sanctions on Iran, while he reiterated that Iran and the US want to make a deal but it's also fine if they don't. (Newswires)

US President Trump previously discussed easing sanctions with advisors on Iran to help secure a Rouhani meeting at UN in which where Treasury Secretary Mnuchin voiced support and former National Security Advisor Bolton argued forcefully against it. (Newswires/Twitter)

Iranian President Rouhani and French President Macron discussed the nuclear pact over the phone in which Rouhani reiterated that the US can join talks if sanctions are removed. (Fars) 

US

US President Trump said the Fed should cut rates to zero or less and then US should refinance its debt. In other news, President Trump was said to be meeting with economic advisers to discuss whether or not the government should reduce capital-gains taxes by indexing them to inflation. (Newswires/WSJ/Twitter)

Mexican President Obrador says the threat of the US imposing tariffs on Mexican goods has decreased following on from their progress on migration. (Newswires)

  • US PPI (Aug) M/M 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.2%). (Newswires)
  • US PPI (Aug) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) helped support indices at the open with some extended gains post its special event on Tuesday. Baker Hughes (BHGE) came under pressure after General Electric (GE) announced it would relinquish its majority stake back to it. Altria (MO) was a laggard thanks to the US FDA implementing a ban on flavoured tobacco e-cigarettes. Boeing (BA) drifted higher, catching tailwinds from constructive comments from its CEO on the 737 MAX. Newmont Mining (NEM) and Micron (MU) opened higher following upgrades at BMO and Longbow, respectively, whereas J.B. Hunt (JBHT) and Costco (COST) opened lower at Loop and Oppenheimer, respectively. Cisco (CSCO) benefitted from an Outperform initiation at Evercore. Uber (UBER) and Lyft (LYFT) opened on the backfoot following California passing in the new bill which requires the pair to class its drivers as official employees, but soon turned into outperformers as participants continue to digest the implications. General Motors (GM) underperformed amid it announcing a 3.5mln vehicle recall in the US as a result of faulty braking systems. S&P 500 0.7% at 3001, NASDAQ-100 0.9% at 7888, Dow Jones 0.9% at 27137.

Fixed Income continued its sell-off on Wednesday, albeit more modestly, with haven demand limited on the back of US-China trade “gestures” and tentativeness ahead of the ECB meeting on Thursday. At settlement the curve had steepened, with yields higher most pronounced in the belly, the 2s10s was 1bps wider, whilst the 10s30s was 1bps narrower. The back-up in yields seen of late is not just confined to the US, it has been global. Analysts note that the rise has been led by real yields, which could be an indication that the market perceives central banks will disappointing in their largesse in the weeks ahead (ECB tomorrow, a package of measures is expected, but recent newsflow has suggested it might not be as aggressive as markets would desire, while the idea of an FOMC 50bps cut has dissipated after Chair Powell's remarks last week). US T-notes (Z9) settled 8 ticks lower at 129-29.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 11th September 2019: SPX hits 3000 amid China’s ‘good gesture’ to the US
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries lower, Crude lower, Dollar higher
  • REAR VIEW: ‘Good gesture’ from China on trade, Trump considered easing sanctions on Iran, PPI beat, More ECB sources
  • COMING UP: Data: Japanese Corporate Goods & Machinery Orders, German & French CPI (Final), EZ Industrial Production, US CPI & Initial Jobless Claims Events: ECB Rate Decision & Press Conference, IEA Monthly Oil Report & JMMC Meeting Supply, CBRT: Italian & US

* ECB PREVIEW: Markets currently fully price in a 10bps reduction in the deposit rate to -0.5% with just over a 40% chance of a deeper cut of 20bps. Of the 70 economists polled by Reuters, around a quarter look for a 20bps reduction with the remainder looking for 10bps. Elsewhere, the survey noted that almost 90% of respondents expected a resumption of bond purchases as of October with a touted monthly amount of EUR 30bln”. In order to mitigate the impact of deeper negative rates on the Eurozone banking sector, around 90% of those surveyed looks for some form of tiering system. Click here for the full RANsquawk preview.

* ECB SOURCES: ECB is to cut some growth projections; both 2019 and 2020 GDP expansion seen not far above 1% and the banks projections on headline and underlying inflation to show a slow protracted rise in the coming years. The sources go on to say that the forecasts suggest that even with a new round of stimulus, the ECB will struggle to hit its inflation target of 2%, something it has failed to do since 2013.

* US/CHINA: China announced that some US products will be exempted from additional 25% tariffs; on the face of it, the news appears to be a trade concession ahead of October talks, however,  the items are mainly lubricants and fodder (and crucially, does not include soybeans, pork, or corn), but is probably more focussed on its own domestic economy, ING believes, pointing out that the US also exempted 110 imported Chinese products from tariffs back in July, most of which were medical equipment and parts, which are high-value products. "If exemptions are viewed as a form of concession, then the US has given more," ING says. "There are still many uncertainties in the coming trade talks. An exemption list of just 16 items will not change China's stance," ING writes, "We believe that China will stand very firm in the negotiations, which will be similar to the last round of talks." US President Trump later said that China had made a “good gesture” with latest exemptions, whilst Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said to the US delegation in Beijing that he believes they have the wisdom to find a solution acceptable to both. However, towards the market close Fox’s Gasparino tweeted a ‘Senior Chinese Diplomat stated China cannot be deterred in anti-poverty efforts, long term growth strategy even amid trade talks; adding they will not make any compromise, even promising to eliminate IP theft, as it would stall growth’.

* TRADE COMMENT: There have been apparently more constructive overtures out of China this week (sweeteners like buying more US ags, exempting some products from additional tariffs). But it is questionable whether these are enough to bridge the large gaps between the two sides and strike a trade deal. China's exemptions of some US products from additional tariffs is similar to the US' moves to delay some tariffs, analysts have said, while the 'sweeteners' reported by SCMP on Tuesday still do not include some of the US' major gripes (like SOE reform). However, the measures do provide President Trump with favourable optics to perhaps delay tariff hikes, slated for mid-December (allowing Trump a 'win' and avoiding measures which Trump has tacitly acknowledged may harm the US consumer). For the Chinese, it provides a sense of calm and progress ahead of the 70th Anniversary of the PRC on 1st October. The kicker here is that while this might not lead to a sustainable trade breakthrough, it might set a friendlier landscape between the two sides, which could keep markets optimistic while central banks are adding to the punch bowl.

* US PPI: US producer prices saw a surprise to the upside in August, although analysts suggest it might be noise, reversing last month’s unusual decline. "The bigger picture is that underlying services inflation remains muted, while any inflationary impact of tariffs is being offset by a weaker renminbi and substitution towards other low-cost producers in Asia," Capital Economics said. Core goods producer prices were unchanged, and CapEco suggest that it implies that any inflationary impact from tariffs has been offset by a weakening renminbi and substitution away from Chinese imports towards other low-cost producers in the region. And this should provide a supporting factor for the Fed to lower rates at its policy meeting next week, CapEco said.

* GEOPOLITICS: US President Trump reportedly considered easing Iranian sanctions which prompted former National Security Advisor Bolton to resign, it was later reported that Us Treasury Secretary Mnuchin expressed support for the move in an effort to secure a meeting between Trump and Iran’s president Rouhani. The Iranian Envoy to the UN said that US National Security Advisor Bolton's departure will not move the nation towards reconsidering discussions with the US, adding that talks cannot commence until the US abandons its policy of economic pressure on Iran. Elsewhere, China’s Ambassador to Germany said that there was sufficient proof that foreign forces intervened in Hong Kong, and that the reception of Hong Kong activist Wong in Berlin has sent a very negative signal for bilateral relations.

* OPEC MONTHLY REPORT: Cut its 2019 oil demand growth forecast by 80k BPD to 1.02mln BPD - in fitting with the EIA’s recent demand growth cut to 0.9mln BPD - citing weaker than expected H1 data from various global demand centres. Both EIA and OPEC have now also cut 2020 global oil demand growth (EIA forecast 1.4mln BPD, OPEC forecasts 1.08mln BPD). OPEC crude production in August rose 136k BPD to average 29.74mln BPD, where output increased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, Iraq and the UAE, while production in Venezuela, Iran, Libya, Kuwait and Algeria declined.

* WTI (V9) SETTLED USD 1.65 LOWER AT USD 55.75/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLED USD 1.57 LOWER AT USD 60.81/BBL: Crude benchmarks both lost over one and a half bucks on the barrel following a mixed EIA inventory report, another forecast downgrade in oil demand growth by OPEC and further signs of easing US-Iran tensions. The EIA reported crude stocks drawing 6.9mln bbls (exp. -2.7mln), slightly less bullish than the API reported 7.2mln bbls draw, where Cushing reported a 0.8mln bbl draw, smaller than the API; products were more bearish than expected with a large 2.7mln bbl build in distillates (exp. +0.07mln) and gasoline drawing 0.68mln bbls, much less than the 4.5mln bbls draw reported by API. Elsewhere in the EIA report, net imports fell by 0.4mln BPD to 3.4mln BPD; production remained at 12.4mln BPD whilst refinery utilisation ramping up 0.3%. Not long after the EIA release bulls were caught offside on the reports that the US had considered easing sanctions on Iran to establish talks between Presidents Trump and Rouhani.

* OPEC JMMC: Ahead of Thursday’s JMMC meeting it appears deeper production cuts from OPEC+ aren’t to be expected in the outset given that kingpin, Russian Energy Minister Novak, said there are no plans to discuss them at the meeting, but did mention that the slowing global demand for oil will be a discussion. There have been contrasting comments however, Iraqi Oil Minister said they will have a discussion on whether or not there is the need for a deeper production cut (something that Oman’s Oil Minister also echoed in an Argus interview), adding that a deeper cut of 1.6mln-1.8mln BPD had been proposed at a previous JMMC meeting (currently 1.2mln BPD). Given the volatile nature of OPEC/OPEC+ meetings, one would be foolish to not consider the possibility of a divergence from the status quo, although consensus going in is for guidance on production cuts to remain as current through H2.

* US T-NOTES (Z9) SETTLES 8 TICKS LOWER AT 129-29. Fixed Income continued its sell-off on Wednesday, albeit more modestly, with haven demand limited on the back of US-China trade “gestures” and tentativeness ahead of the ECB meeting on Thursday. At settlement the curve had steepened, with yields higher most pronounced in the belly, the 2s10s was 1bps wider, whilst the 10s30s was 1bps narrower. The back-up in yields seen of late is not just confined to the US, it has been global. Analysts note that the rise has been led by real yields, which could be an indication that the market perceives central banks will disappointing in their largesse in the weeks ahead (ECB tomorrow, a package of measures is expected, but recent newsflow has suggested it might not be as aggressive as markets would desire, while the idea of an FOMC 50bps cut has dissipated after Chair Powell's remarks last week).

* 10-YEAR AUCTION: The 10-year auction held up okay, with a tail of 0.3bps considered respectful given the recent rate back-up. The slightly above average B/C ratio of 2.46x being complemented by slightly above average Directs and Indirects takedown.

* US 30-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: Thursday's 30s auction is complicated by the ECB policy meeting, as well as the release of August CPI out of the US, both of which are on the slate for before the auction. SocGen's strategists say that, from a relative-value perspective, the 30-year sector appears rich in asset swap versus the previous 30s auction cycle. Recently, five of the six 30-year auctions have tailed, and cover ratios have been easing. "This shows that investors in general are shying away from the 30y auction," SocGen argues, "moreover, the 30-year yield reached an all-time low at end-August, and although it has since increased slightly, it is unlikely that the upcoming auction will attract favourable bidding." On the positive side, the bank notes relatively low dealers’ holdings, as well as the current 30-year trading special in repo, which might be supportive. With that said, the two aforementioned events complicate the auction, adding event risk, and accordingly, SocGen says it is neutral to slightly negative on the auction.

* FX WRAP: USD likely benefited from the firmer than expected PPI data and shrugged off comments from President Trump calling on the Fed to lower rates to ‘Zero or less’. Rate differentials may also be benefitting the green back as US 10-year yields are firmer approaching 1.75%, up from the 1.5530% low earlier in the week. Havens were mixed despite positive trade rhetoric from China where trump quoted it as a ‘good gesture’, JPY was lower on the day as participants await tomorrow's ECB and US CPI on Friday. XAU however was higher with solid gains on the day as it heads towards the key 1500 level; CHF was flat.  EUR was lower against the likes of GBP, JPY and CHF, irrespective of independent drivers for the Pound, Yen and Franc as markets prepare for some degree of stimulus tomorrow. CAD traded lower today against the greenback taking its queue from dollar strength with Canada’s capacity utilisation data beating estimates doing little to provide any strength to the Loonie. Canadian PM Trudeau also officially launched his campaign for an October 21st election, as expected. NZDUSD pulled back to around 0.6408 from 0.6430 ahead of NZ manufacturing PMI and Westpac consumer sentiment on Thursday and Friday respectively, but managed to hold above the big figure as AUDNZD remained between 1.0705-1.0680 parameters. EMFX was mixed, MXN was weaker on the day against the buck and not helped by dovish comments from the Banxico Deputy Governor who stated there is room for more cuts in the upcoming months. TRY was firmer against the greenback heading into tomorrow’s CBRT rate decision where they are expected to cut rates between 175-475bps. BRL derived some support from big Brazilian retail sales beat, with USDBRL down near the base of a 4.0920-0525 range.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.7% at 3001, NASDAQ-100 0.9% at 7888, Dow Jones 0.9% at 27137.

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.2%, Consumer Staples 0.4%, Energy 0%, Financials 0.6%, Health Care 1%, Industrials 1%, Information Technology 1%, Materials 1%, Telecommunication Services 1%, Utilities 1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) helped support indices at the open with some extended gains post its special event on Tuesday. Baker Hughes (BHGE) came under pressure after General Electric (GE) announced it would relinquish its majority stake back to it. Altria (MO) was a laggard thanks to the US FDA implementing a ban on flavoured tobacco e-cigarettes. Boeing (BA) drifted higher, catching tailwinds from constructive comments from its CEO on the 737 MAX. Newmont Mining (NEM) and Micron (MU) opened higher following upgrades at BMO and Longbow, respectively, whereas J.B. Hunt (JBHT) and Costco (COST) opened lower at Loop and Oppenheimer, respectively. Cisco (CSCO) benefitted from an Outperform initiation at Evercore. Uber (UBER) and Lyft (LYFT) opened on the backfoot following California passing in the new bill which requires the pair to class its drivers as official employees, but soon turned into outperformers as participants continue to digest the implications. General Motors (GM) underperformed amid it announcing a 3.5mln vehicle recall in the US as a result of faulty braking systems.

* BREXIT: UK PM Johnson said the UK can manage very well without a Brexit deal and that he wants a high wage, low tax economy. Johnson reiterated his widely known stances that the backstop will be removed, and he will not accept a Northern Ireland only backstop, but they will work for a deal and that great progress has been made. Also, a Scottish court found Johnson’s decision to suspend parliament unlawful, where it will now likely go to the UK Supreme Court. The ‘Operation Yellowhammer’ documents were posted, where they state food prices will increase given the reduced availability and that small businesses are less prepared in the event of a no deal.

* CBRT PREVIEW: All 23 analysts surveyed by Reuters expect the Turkish Central Bank to cut rates, but analysts are split on the size of the move. The magnitude of the cut could be between 175bps and 475bps, according to surveys, with the exact size likely to depend on how the Central Bank views the evolution of inflation. However, desks are cognizant of Turkey’s frail economy, and the Lira’s fragile nature amid geopolitical tensions with the US, as well as President Erdogan’s influence on the Central Bank. It’s also worth keeping in mind that larger-than-forecast move would not be unprecedented, given that the CBRT hiked rates by 625bps in September last year to stem Lira weakness, and a 425bps cut in July which surprised analysts. Meanwhile, pro-government Turkish newspaper Yeni Şafak recently stated that the CBRT may cut rates by 500bp. Click here for full RANsquawk preview.

US Sells USD 24bln of 10-year notes; tails by 0.3bps
content:

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 24bln in 10-year notes re-opening at 1800 EDT/1800 BST
content:
THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wednesday), and a 30-year bond (USD 16bln, Thursday); UBS notes that that there will be around USD 26bln of cashflows (ex-SOMA) this week, including USD 24bln of redemptions and USD 2bln of coupons.

10-YEAR PREVIEW: Analysts at SocGen says the 10-year part of the curve does not have clear set-up for the upcoming auction from a relative value perspective, arguing that it appears rich on asset swap versus the previous 10-year auction cycle, though it does look cheap on the curve versus 5s and 30s. SocGen says the steepening of 2s10s seen since late August, however, does make the sector look attractive, though the bank highlights that 2s10s has actually flattened by around 10bps since the previous auction cycle (NOTE: August's auction was soft). On the other side of the coin, SocGen observes that the current 10-year note trades special in repo, and dealer holdings in the 7-10 year bucket is low; both of these factors could be supportive for the auction. "Even so," SocGen writes, "the auction will likely demand a concession to go well, as the current when-issued yield is well below all auction stops since August 2016." The bank says it is neutral on the September 10-year auction.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar proffers at the expense of others and as yield squeeze persists
content:
USD

Firmer than forecast US PPI on the eve of headline inflation on Thursday probably contributed to the Dollar’s broad fillip, but the DXY broke out of its early week range mainly, if not entirely to more pronounced Euro weakness ahead of tomorrow’s ECB policy decision(s) and President Draghi’s penultimate press conference/Q&A. Indeed, the index cleared 98.500 in tandem with EUR/Usd losing grip of the 1.1000 handle and then extended gains to 98.746, exposing 98.967 (September 4 high) before 99.000 and the 2019 peak (99.370 set just the day before and all pre-NFP).

EUR

Pre-ECB positioning also pushed the single currency down against the likes of the GBP, JPY and CHF, irrespective of independent drivers for the Pound, Yen and France, with the crosses down towards 0.8900 (and near Monday’s 0.8905 low), through 118.50 and back under 1.0950 respectively, as markets prepare for some degree of stimulus – full preview available via our headline feed and Research Suite. However, Cable also retreated from best levels towards its wtd base (1.2307) amidst more UK parliament/Brexit reverberations as a Scottish High Court concluded that PM Johnson broke the law by suspending the HoC. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy soaked up exporter offers around 107.50 on the way to 107.85 and then losing momentum and has returned to a cloud top, and Usd/Chf looks ripe to revisit 0.9950 amidst positive/constructive Chinese moves on trade (US tariff exemptions and a goodwill gesture to restart buying some goods).

AUD/CAD/NZD 

Choppy trade across the board with early strength vs their US counterpart dissipating due to the aforementioned Greenback bounce and Aud/Usd drifting down to 0.6850 at one stage vs circa 0.6885 at the other end of the spectrum, while Usd/Cad rebounded from 1.3140 to 1.3180 even though Canadian cap u came in above consensus, as current PM Trudeau kicked off this campaign to retain office at the October 21 election and crude eased off the gas. Back down under, Nzd/Usd pulled back to around 0.6408 from 0.6430 ahead of NZ manufacturing PMI and Westpac consumer sentiment on Thursday and Friday respectively, but managed to hold above the big figure as Aud/Nzd remained between 1.0705-1.0680 parameters.

SEK/NOK 

After early underperformance, the Scandi Crowns look set to end the midweek EU session on a more even keel, as the Euro weakness noted above spread and cushioned the Norwegian Krona from a downturn in oil prices. Hence, Eur/Sek is still hovering around 10.6500, but Eur/Nok has reversed further from circa 9.9000 to just above 9.8600.

EM 

Far from a role-reversal, but the Zar and Try have flipped sides ahead of Thursday’s CBRT rate verdict as the Lira pares some lost ground vs the Dollar from 5.7900+ to 5.7500 or a bit better at one stage, while Usd/Zar bounced firmly ahead of 14.6100 and multi-week lows. Elsewhere, the Real derived some support from big Brazilian retail sales beat, with Usd/Brl down near the base of a 4.0920-0525 range, but Usd/Mxn traded closer to the top of its 19.565-4795 band even though Mexican IP matched expectations and President Obrador claimed that progress with the US on migration has lengthened the odds of tariffs on Mexican goods.

Market Update: US equity futures quickly reverse losses at the open, financials lag
content: Equity futures saw some downside at the open, but quickly reversed and are now trading inline with the cash market, which is now slightly higher (at the time of writing) from yesterday’s close. Energy is the leading sectors, with higher crude prices (post bullish API data). Tech is currently in second place, with Apple (AAPL) leading the Dow after its much-touted product launch yesterday revealed a cheaper iPhone and a new competitively priced TV streaming service (which is weighing on Netflix (NFLX), Roku (ROKU) and Disney (DIS)). Lagging are the typically defensive utilities and consumer staples sectors along with consumer discretionary. At the bottom of the pack is Financials, who are lower despite higher yields, seemingly marking a change in the trend observed in recent days, which has seen value sectors (financials, energy) gain at the expense of momentum/large cap tech and haven sectors (utilities, consumer staples).

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 11th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has been upgraded to Buy from Neutral at Longbow
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is recalling almost 3.5mln vehicles
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) is to sell USD 250mln of Baker Hughes’ (BHGE) (Energy/Oil & Gas Equipment & Services) stock back to it

11th September 2019

  • Market sentiment is tentative ahead of Thursday’s ECB and following mixed signals in the current US-China trade spat, where certain tariff exemptions have been made by China (effective September 17th), although key issues remain such as IP and government subsidies, with debate over whether this is temporary optimism or an olive branch for more reconciliation between the two sides.
  • Of note for financial exchanges (CME, ICE, NYSE), Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing have proposed a merger with LSE (LSE LN), the terms of proposed deal would imply an enterprise value of GBP 31.6bln, valuing each LSE share at GBP 83.61. LSE has since said it would consider the bid.
  • Of note for automakers (F, GM, FCAU, TSLA), China Vehicle Sales (Aug) Y/Y -6.9% (Prev. -4.3%), Jan-Aug sales -11% (Prev. +3.5%). An industry Association official said Chinese autos sales are to see negative to low growth over the next 3 years.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) – Following Apple’s special event on Tuesday, Piper Jaffray’s Michael Olson has described it as “more incremental than dramatic,” and doesn’t expect TV Plus and Arcade to be material to estimates in the near-term. Citi’s Jim Suva believes the announcements were positive for Apple’s service offerings, whereas Nomura’s Jeffrey Kvaal described the event as "marginally disappointing even relative to low expectations" and that “pitfalls remain” in Apple’s Q1. Although Bernstein’s A.M. Sacconaghi, Jr. sees the year bundle of TV+ with hardware – and the low subscription price post-trial - as "extremely clever".
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) is looking to divest its FoxNext gaming unit that it recently acquired as part of its acquisition of Fox’s (FOXA) entertainment assets earlier this year.

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is being probed by the FTC, who are interviewing merchants to determine if the retail behemoth is harming its competition.
  • Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) has been downgraded to Perform from Outperform at Oppenheimer, where analyst Rupesh Parikh sees limited upside at current valuations.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is being “closely” monitored by FATF, the global anti-money laundering watchdog, who want to address risks associated with its proposed Libra cryptocurrency.
  • Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has been upgraded to Buy from Neutral at Longbow, where analyst Nikolay Todorov sees upside in its FY20 financials due to raised pricing fundamental forecasts in DRAM and NAND.

S&P 500

  • Alliance Data Systems (ADS) (Information Technology/Data Processing & Outsourced Services) has been upgraded to Buy from Neutral at Goldman Sachs, where analyst Ryan Nash sees current valuation as a favourable risk/reward skew following the Co’s string of disappointments in recent years (ADS down 57% from its peak in 2015).
  • Charles Schwab Corporation (SCHW) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) is to cut 3% of its brokerage staff (600 positions) in cost cutting efforts, where WSJ reports the cuts could come as soon as next week.
  • Deere & Co. (DE) (Industrials/Agricultural & Farm Machinery) reported North American 3-month rolling retail sales for August. 2WD tractors between 40-100 PTO hp, sales were up low single digit, compared to the industry down 1%. 2WD tractors over 100 PTO hp, sales were down more than the industry, which was down 4%. Combine sales were down more than the industry, which was down 24%.
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) is to sell USD 250mln of Baker Hughes’ (BHGE) (Energy/Oil & Gas Equipment & Services) stock back to it, relinquishing its majority stake in the oilfield services Co and also cutting GE board designation to one from five.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is recalling almost 3.5mln vehicles to address a braking issue that could increase risks of a crash, according to company filing with NHTSA.
  • Morgan Stanley (MS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) has affirmed its 2018 to 2019 strategic alternatives of ROE 10%-13%, ROTCE 11.5%-14.5%, at the Barclays conference. CFO says Co continues to see good demand for credit products.
  • Philip Morris International (PM) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco) has raised its quarterly dividend to USD 1.17/shr from USD 1.14/shr.

OTHER

  • Altice USA Inc (ATUS) (Communication Services/Media) issued a statement acknowledging that several funds advised by BC Partners and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board had elected to sell 20mln Class A shares, cutting their overall stake by 40% leaving their combined stake in Altice at 4.4%.
  • Dave & Buster's (PLAY) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) Q2 19 (USD): EPS 0.90 (exp. 0.84), Revenue 344.6mln (exp. 344.3mln), SSS -1.8%; increases share buyback by 200mln to 800mln. Cuts FY Revenue view below expectations.
  • EQT Corporation (EQT) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) has announced reorganisation (streamlining the company to 15 units from 58) and workforce reduction (equating to approximately 23%).
  • Uber Inc (UBER) (Industrials/Road & Rail), Lyft (LYFT) (Industrials/Road & Rail) – The two ride-hailing companies have faced a defeat in California, as was previously suggested, where the bill which would class its drivers as employees has passed in the State Senate, which will be effective January 1st, 2020, NYT reports.
  • Zscaler Inc (ZS) (Information Technology/Software) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.07 (exp. 0.01), Revenue 0.086bln (exp. 0.083bln). FY20 EPS view 0.12-0.15 (exp. 0.19), FY20 Revenue view 0.395bln-0.405bln (exp. 0.403bln). Co sees large scale deals as increasingly harder to close.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 11th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities are firmer this morning supported by China releasing a US tariff exemption list, subsequently Commerce Ministry noted that certain agreements may be reached prior to October meeting
  • US President Trump says Fed should cut rates to zero or less, and then US should refinance its debt
  • Amazon (AMZN) are to be probed by antitrust officials in the US regarding their Marketplace platform
  • Scottish Court has ruled that PM Johnson's proroguing of parliament is illegal
  • Looking ahead, highlights US PPI & DoEs, US 10yr supply

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly higher as the region shrugged-off the indecision from Wall St, which had been subdued by the continued global bond rout and tentativeness ahead of this week's ECB. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were higher but with gains in Australia capped as the outperformance in mining names was counterbalanced by weakness in tech, while Tokyo exporters continued to reap the benefits of recent currency weakness and after source reports suggested BoJ policymakers could be open to additional easing measures. Advances were also seen across the Apple supply chain in Japan and Taiwan following the tech giant’s launch event where it announced a new streaming service and health app, as well as new iWatch, iPhone and iPad models. Hang Seng (+1.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were mixed after a tepid PBoC liquidity effort in which the mainland failed to take impetus from China’s fresh efforts to further open its financial markets by dropping QFII and RQFII quota limits. Sources noted China is ready to sweeten a deal by buying US goods, however, the report added that a purchase agreement is no certainty and would be in exchange for a delay on tariffs as well as an easing of restrictions on Huawei. China’s Global Times Editor also later suggested China will introduce important measures to ease the impact from the trade war which would benefit some companies from both China and the US which briefly fuelled appetite for risk. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid a continuation of the global bond rout which was partly attributed to this week's supply and heavy corporate issuances, with weaker results across all metrics in today’s 5yr JGB auction adding to the pressure.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0843 vs. Exp. 7.0870 (Prev. 7.0846)

China Global Times Editor tweeted 'Based on what I know, China will introduce important measures to ease the negative impact of the trade war. The measures will benefit some companies from both China and the US.'. (Twitter)

China releases tariff exemption list for products from the US; takes effect on September 17th., Xinhua

- Items on the list will not be subject to additional tariffs imposed by China on US goods as countermeasures to trade action taken by the US

- Exemptions include food products and lubricants; though does not list corn, soybeans or pork

- Will consider tariff exemptions for additional products which are imported from the US

Tariff exemption list by China is a goodwill gesture amidst the resumption of trade talks, Global Times; China and the US may reach certain agreements before a scheduled meeting in early October, according to an expert close to the Ministry of Commerce. (Global Times)

US

US President Trump says Fed should cut rates to zero or less, and then US should refinance its debt. (Newswires)

Russian intelligence agency are looking into the case of alleged US spying in the Russian presidential election., according to the Kremlin. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Saudi Arabia condemned Israel PM Netanyahu's plan to annex parts of West Bank and called for a meeting of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation foreign ministers to discuss the move. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson's decision to suspend Parliament is unlawful, according to a Scottish Court via a lawyer, as such the case will now go to the UK Supreme Court on Tuesday; as of yet no order has been given to suspend the UK Supreme Court. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson reiterated to the Cabinet that he will not negotiate Brexit delay in Brussels on October 17th-18th and that his Brexit goal is unchanged by law passed by Parliament, according to ITV's editor citing sources. (Twitter)

UK PM Johnson is mulling plans for a regulatory border in the Irish Sea as he seeks a new Brexit “divorce” deal with the EU, according to The Telegraph. The move would see an all-Ireland zone for checks on most goods crossing between the north and south Ireland, thus removing the need for a backstop. (Telegraph)

DUP leader Foster later stated that an all-Ireland backstop idea has been dismissed by UK PM Johnson. (Newswires/ITV/Twitter)

UK opposition Labour Party Deputy Leader Watson is calling for a Brexit referendum to be conducted before a snap election. (Huffington Post)

UK MPs seeking to block a no-deal are reportedly examining ways to bring back a version of former PM May’s Brexit deal with a 2nd referendum attached. Sources added that the cross-party motion is gathering strength as more current and former Conservative MP’s are accepting of the idea. (Guardian)

ComRes Poll showed a majority of the public back UK PM Johnson over Brexit according to Telegraph, while the poll also showed Conservatives with 30% (-1) of support and Labour with 29% (+2) of support. (Telegraph/Twitter)

IFW cuts Germany’s 2019 GDP growth forecast to 0.4% from 0.6%; 2020 GDP growth forecast cut to 1.0% from 1.6%. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses are broadly in the green [Eurostoxx 50 +0.5%], following on from a similar APAC lead as sentiment is supported by China releasing a tariff exemption list for the US, effective from September 17th. Items on the list will not be subject to additional tariffs imposed by China on US goods as countermeasures to trade action taken by the US, however, the list does not include corn, soybean or pork. Spain’s IBEX (U/C) is the underperformer thus far amid disappointing earnings from heavyweight Inditex (-2.9%) whilst broad-based gains are seen across the region. Sectors are mixed with defensive sectors lagging, although the energy sector also feels some headwind from yesterday’s price decline in the oil complex. Turning to individual movers, LSE (+5.6%) shares spiked higher amid reports that Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing have proposed a combination with LSE, terms of proposed deal would imply an enterprise value of GBP 31.6bln, and the transaction implies a value of GBP 83.61 for each LSE share. LSE said its board will consider the proposal. On the flip side, Suez (-1.3%) and Kone (-1.9%) opened lower amid downgrades, although the former saw some upside amid reports that the Co. won an approx. EUR 1bln treatment contract for the Dongying China chemical plant, contract is for 50 years.

Amazon (AMZN) are to be probed by antitrust officials in the US regarding their Marketplace platform. (Newswires)

FX

EUR - Not quite the biggest G10 loser or underperformer, but the single currency has been a notable mover after topping out above 1.1050 against the Dollar and failing to close above key resistance just below yet again (1.1049 represents a 38.2% retracement of the decline from 1.1249 to 1.0926 ytd low). Eur/Gbp selling into the early 9 am fix may also have impacted, as the cross retests recent sub-0.8925 lows, but Eur/Usd is holding around the 10 DMA and bids said to be sitting just below (at 1.1022 and 1.1020 respectively) with one eye on Thursday’s ECB meeting and some form of easing/stimulus as German institutes continue to downgrade GDP estimates, while the other keeps tabs on higher global bond yields/spreads.

JPY/CHF - More safe-haven unwinding has nudged the Yen and Franc down to circa 107.85 and 0.9940 vs the Buck, and Usd/Jpy has breached a Fib, exporter offers plus a cloud top formation in the process, at 107.49, 107.50 and 107.71, with some fundamental/macro impetus stemming from another upturn in US Treasury yields and more curve steepening against the backdrop of positive-looking US-China trade headlines (such as Chinese tariff exemptions and buying US goods as a sweetener for upcoming talks).

GBP/AUD/NZD/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with Cable forming multiple/lower peaks ahead of 1.2400 and reported stops at 1.2385+ and the Aussie fading into 0.6900 and the 100 DMA at 0.6907 following another downbeat sentiment survey overnight (Westpac consumer confidence turned negative). However, the Pound has not seen much angst in wake of an official ruling in Scotland against UK PM Johnson’s Parliament prorogation, while Aud/Usd is still outpacing Nzd/Usd as the latter remains heavy on the 0.6400 handle and the Kiwi struggles to stay above 1.0700 in cross terms ahead of NZ manufacturing PMI tomorrow and Westpac’s Q3 consumer survey on Friday. Elsewhere, the Loonie is maintaining its post-Canadian jobs momentum, but finding 1.3150 a tough hurdle to overcome convincingly.

NOK/SEK - Even though crude prices remain on a roll and the Norges Bank is still on course to take another step towards policy normalisation before the Riksbank (albeit not likely next week given yesterday’s soft inflation data), Eur/Nok is hovering around 9.8850 within a 9.9010-9.8765 range in contrast to Eur/Sek nearer the base of 10.6990-6595 parameters in wake of latest Riksbank comments reaffirming tightening guidance and dismissing weaker than expected Swedish CPI/CPIF metrics.

EM - The Rand’s bull run has been derailed around 14.6100 vs the Dollar and a deterioration in SA business confidence has hardly helped as Usd/Zar rebounds to 14.7000+, even though Moody’s indicated low risk of a ratings downgrade this year.

Notable FX Expiries:

- EUR/USD: 1.0990-1.1000 (1.3BLN), 1.1050 (414M)

Australian Westpac Consumer Confidence (Sep) -1.7% (Prev. 3.6%). (Newswires)

FIXED

It was looking ominous when Bunds pierced yesterday’s Eurex low, Fib support and the next downside chart level to trade at 173.65, but alongside Eurozone debt counterparts the ensuing bounce has been pretty pronounced if not encouraging or compelling. Indeed, the 10 year benchmark just reached 174.07 (+9 ticks vs -33 ticks at one stage) before waning vs Gilts that remain 35 ticks adrift, albeit off a 131.99 Liffe base (-59 ticks) and US Treasuries still soft/steeper, though also above overnight session troughs with the curve not as steep as it has been. Perhaps more pre-ECB positioning has prompted the turnaround, but more immediately US PPI forms a precursor for CPI on Thursday and 10 year supply comes with a bit more of a concession at 1.70%+ after last night’s rather tepid 3 year sale.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are holding onto most of its intra-day gains/consolidation following yesterday’s decline which was induced by the EIA cutting its 2019 and 2020 global oil demand forecasts by 100k BPD and 30k BPD, whilst downside was exacerbated after US President Trump fired the White House National Security Advisor/known policy-hawk Bolton. Prices have rebounded and remain on an upward trajectory thus far with WTI futures around the 58.00/bbl mark whilst its Brent counterpart trades just under 63.00/bbl (at time of writing). This morning also saw the release of the OPEC Monthly Oil Report in which its 2019 global oil demand growth forecast was revised lower by 80k BPD, in-fitting with the EIA STEO, next up IEA will release its report tomorrow at 0900BST. Ahead of tomorrow’s JMMC meeting, the Iraqi Oil Minister noted that the producers will have a discussion on whether or not there is the need for a deeper production cut with OPEC+, although this was rebuffed by the Russian Energy Minister who also expressed concern regarding global economy. Novak added that the slowing global demand for oil will also be discussed at the meeting tomorrow. Elsewhere, gold prices remain capped below the 1500/oz ahead of this week’s key risk events including US CPI and the ECB rate decision, whilst copper prices are little changed with little by way of immediate catalyst. Finally, Dalian iron ore prices rose for a third session amid a decline in shipments coupled with hopes of further Chinese stimulus.

US White House invited biofuel company executives to meet regarding the stalled biofuel policy deal. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak says current oil prices are defined by the market, he did not discuss the possibility of oil prices rising with Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz, only discussed cooperation with OPEC+ alliance. (Newswires)

- says he is concerned by the slowdown in the global economy, says OPEC+ will discuss the slowing global demand for oil. (Newswires)

Iraqi Oil Minister says they will have a discussion on whether or not there is the need for a deeper production cut with OPEC+ at the JMMC meeting. (Newswires)

OPEC Monthly Oil Report: For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.02mln BPD; down 80k BPD from the prior report; OPEC crude production in August rose 136k BPD to average 29.74mln BPD, according to secondary sources

subject: Atlantia (ATL IM) - Italian PD Senator Chief said he does not think the Co's motorway concession will be revoked as it is very difficult legally

OPEC MONTHLY OIL REPORT:  For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.02mln BPD; down 80k BPD from the prior report; OPEC crude production in August rose 136k BPD to average 29.74mln BPD, according to secondary sources
content:
• OPEC says the cut in global oil demand growth forecast can be attributed to weaker-than-expected H1 2019 data from various global demand centres and slower 2019 economic growth projections.
  • Crude oil output increased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, Iraq and the UAE, while production in Venezuela, Iran, Libya, Kuwait and Algeria declined.
  • Preliminary data indicates that global oil supply in August rose 830k BPD to average 99.24mln BPD, compared to the previous month
  • In 2020, world oil demand is forecast to increase 1.08mln BPD Y/Y (vs. Prev. 1.14mln BPD)
  • OPEC says OECD total product inventories rose in July to 30.8mln barrels, 55mln barrels above the latest five-year average.
  • Demand for OPEC crude for 2019 was revised down by 100k BPD from the previous report to stand at 30.6mln BPD, 1mln BPD lower than the 2018 level. 2020 OPEC demand remains at 29.4mln BPD (unchanged from prior report)
  • The non-OPEC oil supply growth forecast for 2019 has been revised up by 10k BPD from prior report to reach 1.99mln BPD Y/Y. OPEC says “Upward revisions to oil production from Russia, Kazakhstan, Australia and Canada outpaced a downward revision to the US oil supply forecast.”
  • In 2020, non-OPEC oil supply is projected to grow by 2.25mln BPD (revised down by 136k BPD from the prior report), is mainly due to a large downward revision to US oil supply, which is now expected to grow by 1.54 mln BPD (revised down by 165k BPD from prior report)
analysis_details:
• Aspects of the OPEC Monthly Report are in-fitting with the EIA Short-Term Energy Outlook in which it cut 2019 world oil demand growth by 100k BPD to 900k BPD. Both EIA and OPEC also cut 2020 global oil demand (EIA forecast 1.4mln BPD, OPEC expects 1.08mln BPD).
  • Note: Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that OPEC+ will discuss the slowing global demand for oil at tomorrow's JMMC meeting

Nomura attribute the recent divergence in momentum vs value equity to a steepening yield curve
content:
• Nomura note that since the GFC, the slope of the Treasury yield curve has had a powerful influence on a number of factors, including value and momentum. The fall in momentum and rally in recent days provides an excellent example, the banks says. Since last Thursday (through Tuesday 1pm), as the yield curve steepened, momentum has lost more than 11% while value has gained 7%, as seen in the chart below:
  • Nomura’s main point is that the extreme factor moves seen seeing in the equity market in recent days are driven by activity in the fixed income market and this cross-asset connection has been important in the post GFC era. Going forward, the bank argues, what happens next to momentum and value is tied to what happens to the yield curve.

Gilts gap down partly in catch-up trade, Short Sterling futures resume retracement
content: UK debt and STIR contracts have picked up pretty much where they left off on Tuesday, with bears still controlling proceedings amidst in wake of latest Brexit bills designed to prevent or materially reduce the chances of no deal, Chinese concessions on US trade via tariff exemptions and a good will offers to start buying some goods again, and this week’s dose of mainly better than expected domestic data. Gilts attempted to pare some losses in early Liffe trade, but in keeping with their peers upticks are being faded faster/more frequently and the 10 year bond has already slipped back towards the bottom of a 132.49-19 range vs yesterday’s 132.58 close, as the 3 month strip sits 0.5-4 ticks below par.

subject: Iranian Envoy to the UN says National Security Advisor Bolton's departure will not move the nation towards reconsidering discussions with the US, according to IRNA
content: • Talks cannot commence until the US abandons its policy of economic pressure on Iran

subject: Bunds: hanging on for ECB lifeline
content: The 10 year German benchmark has drifted into a lower range in line with the latest downturn in US Treasuries and retested yesterday’s low just ahead of nearest technical support in the form of a Fib retracement level at 173.72 following a relatively tame rebound to 173.97 vs Tuesday’s 173.98 Eurex close. As such, rebounds are becoming less pronounced and convincing, but the -50 bp cash yield may provide a bit more resistance and a buffer for futures into the ECB meeting. For reference, Bunds are currently hovering around -54 bp, circa 20 bp above record lows registered just over a week ago on September 3.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

11th September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly higher as the region shrugged-off the indecision from Wall St, which had been subdued by the continued global bond rout and tentativeness ahead of this week's ECB. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) were higher but with gains in Australia capped as the outperformance in mining names was counterbalanced by weakness in tech, while Tokyo exporters continued to reap the benefits of recent currency weakness and after source reports suggested BoJ policymakers could be open to additional easing measures. Advances were also seen across the Apple supply chain in Japan and Taiwan following the tech giant’s launch event where it announced a new streaming service and health app, as well as new iWatch, iPhone and iPad models. Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were mixed after a tepid PBoC liquidity effort in which the mainland failed to take impetus from China’s fresh efforts to further open its financial markets by dropping QFII and RQFII quota limits. In terms of recent commentary, White House Trade Adviser Navarro suggested investors play the long game regarding China and although sources noted China is ready to sweeten a deal by buying US goods, the reports added that a purchase agreement is no certainty and would be in exchange for a delay on tariffs as well as an easing of restrictions on Huawei. China’s Global Times Editor also later suggested China will introduce important measures to ease the impact from the trade war which would benefit some companies from both China and the US which briefly fuelled appetite for risk.

FTSE 100

Oil names - WTI crude futures recouped some of the prior day’s losses which had been triggered by the US EIA downgrade of global oil demand and an unwinding of the geopolitical risk premium after news that US President Trump fired National Security Adviser and foreign policy hawk Bolton. Nonetheless, prices have since rebounded of their lows with WTI eyeing a reclaim of the USD 58.00/bbl level, helped by the larger than expected draw in API crude inventories. (RANsquawk)

Just Eat (JE/ LN) – A TV advert for Deliveroo has been banned by the Advertising Standards Authority as it is likely to mislead customers by implying that Deliveroo could deliver food anywhere within the UK. (BBC)

IAG (IAG LN) – Co. state it will take ‘some time’ before British Airways services return to normal following the two-day strike. (BBC)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Man Group (EMG LN) – Co. will reportedly announce today the departure of its President, Jonathan Sorrell, after eight years in the company. Sources stated that the resignation is not connected to other potential boardroom changes. (Sky News)

Cobham (COB LN) – Co’s leading shareholder Sanderson Asset Management said it was “inclined to vote against” the planned GBP 4bln takeover by US’ Advent International. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 11th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly higher as the region shrugged-off the indecision from Wall St
  • China is ready to sweeten deal by buying American goods in countdown to trade war talks according to SCMP sources
  • UK MPs seeking to block a no-deal are reportedly examining ways to bring back a version of former PM May’s Brexit deal with a 2nd referendum attached
  • US President Trump said he has removed National Security Advisor John Bolton and that he disagreed strongly with some of Bolton's suggestions
  • Apple announced a new streaming service and health app, as well as new iWatch, iPhone and iPad models
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US PPI & DoEs, OPEC Monthly Report, US 10yr supply

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly higher as the region shrugged-off the indecision from Wall St, which had been subdued by the continued global bond rout and tentativeness ahead of this week's ECB. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) were higher but with gains in Australia capped as the outperformance in mining names was counterbalanced by weakness in tech, while Tokyo exporters continued to reap the benefits of recent currency weakness and after source reports suggested BoJ policymakers could be open to additional easing measures. Advances were also seen across the Apple supply chain in Japan and Taiwan following the tech giant’s launch event where it announced a new streaming service and health app, as well as new iWatch, iPhone and iPad models. Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were mixed after a tepid PBoC liquidity effort in which the mainland failed to take impetus from China’s fresh efforts to further open its financial markets by dropping QFII and RQFII quota limits. Sources noted China is ready to sweeten a deal by buying US goods, however, the report added that a purchase agreement is no certainty and would be in exchange for a delay on tariffs as well as an easing of restrictions on Huawei. China’s Global Times Editor also later suggested China will introduce important measures to ease the impact from the trade war which would benefit some companies from both China and the US which briefly fuelled appetite for risk. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid a continuation of the global bond rout which was partly attributed to this week's supply and heavy corporate issuances, with weaker results across all metrics in today’s 5yr JGB auction adding to the pressure.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0843 vs. Exp. 7.0870 (Prev. 7.0846)

China is ready to sweeten deal by buying American goods in countdown to trade war talks according to a source, although reports added even a simple purchase agreement is no certainty and that purchasing of US goods would be in exchange for a delay on tariffs and easing of restrictions on Huawei. Furthermore, China could offer more market access and better IP protection as well as cutting industrial capacity, but would be reluctant to compromise on subsidies, industrial policies and reform of SOEs. (SCMP)

China Global Times Editor tweeted 'Based on what I know, China will introduce important measures to ease the negative impact of the trade war. The measures will benefit some companies from both China and the US.'. (Twitter)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said it is a grave concern for US President Trump's administration that the Chinese did not live up to its commitments to purchase US Agricultural goods and that this matter will be addressed in upcoming talks. (NY Times) 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reiterated to the Cabinet that he will not negotiate Brexit delay in Brussels on October 17th-18th and that his Brexit goal is unchanged by law passed by Parliament, according to ITV's editor citing sources. (Twitter)

UK PM Johnson is mulling plans for a regulatory border in the Irish Sea as he seeks a new Brexit “divorce” deal with the EU, according to The Telegraph. The move would see an all-Ireland zone for checks on most goods crossing between the north and south Ireland, thus removing the need for a backstop. (Telegraph)

A senior ERG source said if UK PM Johnson goes for an all-Ireland backstop that 'throws the DUP under the bus', the deal would not get through the Commons, while DUP leader Foster later stated that an all-Ireland backstop idea has been dismissed by UK PM Johnson. (Newswires/ITV/Twitter)

UK opposition Labour Party Deputy Leader Watson is calling for a Brexit referendum to be conducted before a snap election. (Huffington Post)

UK MPs seeking to block a no-deal are reportedly examining ways to bring back a version of former PM May’s Brexit deal with a 2nd referendum attached. Sources added that the cross-party motion is gathering strength as more current and former Conservative MP’s are accepting of the idea. (Guardian)

ComRes Poll showed a majority of the public back UK PM Johnson over Brexit according to Telegraph, while the poll also showed Conservatives with 30% (-1) of support and Labour with 29% (+2) of support. (Telegraph/Twitter)

FX

 

DXY was flat as price action remained contained within this week’s tight range amid the Fed blackout period and a lack of significant releases prior to tomorrow’s inflation data. The greenback’s major counterparts were also uneventful with EUR/USD stuck around 1.1050 ahead of the upcoming ECB meeting. GBP/USD traded sideways at the mid-1.2300 handle with Parliament suspended and PM Johnson reiterating he will not negotiate a Brexit delay in Brussels on October 17th-18th. Elsewhere, USD/JPY continued its gradual advances amid gains in Japanese stocks and with focus centred around today’s Cabinet reshuffle, while antipodeans were indecisive with early losses in AUD amid weaker Westpac Consumer Confidence and as NAB added to its RBA rate cut forecasts in which it now sees the Cash Rate Target lowered to 0.50% by February 2020 vs. Prev. forecast of 0.75%. However, antipodeans then gradually recovered which was exacerbated after the Global Times Editor tweeted regarding China measures to ease the impact from the trade dispute.

Australian Westpac Consumer Confidence (Sep) -1.7% (Prev. 3.6%). (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly higher in which WTI crude futures recouped some of the prior day’s losses which had been triggered by the US EIA downgrade of global oil demand and an unwinding of the geopolitical risk premium after news that US President Trump fired National Security Adviser and foreign policy hawk Bolton. Nonetheless, prices have since rebounded of their lows with WTI eyeing a reclaim of the USD 58.00/bbl level, helped by the larger than expected draw in API crude inventories. Elsewhere, gold was flat amid an uneventful greenback, while copper was gradually supported as the risk tone improved and after the encouraging tweet from China’s Global Times Editor regarding measures.

 

API Crude Inventories -7.2mln vs. Exp. -2.7mln (Prev. +0.4mln). (Newswires)

 

OPEC Secretary-General Barkindo said there are no alternative plans for OPEC+ agreement and that it is committed to taking the necessary decisions to ensure the stability and balance of the global oil market. (Newswires)

 

US EIA cut forecasts for 2019 world oil demand growth by 100K BPD to a 900k BPD Y/Y increase and cut 2020 world oil demand growth by 30k to a 1.4mln BPD y/y increase, while it sees 2019 US crude output to rise 1.25mln BPD to 12.24mln BPD and sees 2020 US crude output to rise 990k BPD to 13.23mln BPD. (Newswires)

A Senior US Energy Official said the US will continue maximum pressure campaign on Iran and will monitor the oil shipments as well as consider the designation of identified parties purchasing Iranian oil. (Newswires)

 

US White House invited biofuel company executives to meet regarding the stalled biofuel policy deal. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

Saudi Arabia condemned Israel PM Netanyahu's plan to annex parts of West Bank and called for a meeting of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation foreign ministers to discuss the move. (Newswires)

 

US

Yields jumped across the curve by between 8-9bps at settlement, though major curve spreads were around 1bps narrower. Better risk sentiment -- where talks/between US and China are progressing, with some suggestions of compromises, while geopolitics regarding US/Iran is moving in a friendlier direction after the sacking of WH Adviser Bolton -- as well as hopes of stimulus from the ECB this week (and likely looser policy from the Fed next week, with sources suggesting the BOJ could join the party too) have lessened the need for safer assets. This week's supply and heavy corporate issuance were also said to have weighed on the complex. US T-notes (Z9) settled 22+ ticks lower at 130-05.

US President Trump said he has removed National Security Advisor John Bolton and that he disagreed strongly with some of Bolton's suggestions. (Newswires)

content:
Asia equity markets trade somewhat mixed following the indecisive performance on Wall St amid a continued global bond rout and tentativeness ahead of this week's ECB. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) are higher but with gains in Australia capped as outperformance in mining names is counterbalanced by weakness in tech, while Tokyo exporters continue to reap the benefits of recent currency weakness and after source reports suggested BoJ policymakers could be open to additional easing measures. Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) are mixed after a tepid PBoC liquidity effort and as the mainland fails to take impetus from China’s fresh efforts to further open its financial markets by dropping QFII and RQFII quota limits. In addition, White House Trade Adviser Navarro suggested investors play the long game regarding China and although sources noted China is ready to sweeten a deal by buying US goods, the reports added that a purchase agreement is no certainty and would be in exchange for a delay on tariffs as well as an easing of restrictions on Huawei.

In FX markets, the DXY is flat as price action remains contained within this week’s tight range with the Fed on a blackout period and amid a lack of significant releases prior to tomorrow’s inflation data. The greenback’s major counterparts are also uneventful with EUR/USD stuck around 1.1050 as markets await the upcoming ECB meeting where markets are fully pricing in a 10bps cut into deeper negative territory for the Deposit Rate and with many expecting a package of measures, although sources have suggested there could be a delay of the launch of QE and there was strong disagreement over how much stimulus was required. GBP/USD trades sideways at the mid-1.2300 handle with Parliament suspended and PM Johnson reiterating he will not negotiate a Brexit delay in Brussels on October 17th-18th. Elsewhere, USD/JPY continues its gradual advances amid gains in Japanese stocks and with focus centred around today’s Cabinet reshuffle, while antipodeans are indecisive with early weakness in AUD amid weaker Westpac Consumer Confidence and as NAB added to its RBA rate cut forecasts in which it now sees the Cash Rate Target lowered to 0.50% by February 2020 vs. Prev. forecast of 0.75%.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower amid a continuation of the global bond rout which was partly attributed to this week's supply and heavy corporate issuances, while participants are also sidelined ahead of today’s 5yr JGB auction.

Sun Hung Kai Properties (16 HK) - Co. is said to offer apartments in Hong Kong at discount of 25%. (SCMP)

Property - China is to take measures to reduce use of credit cards to purchase real estate, while it was also reported that Hong Kong luxury home rents saw double-digit declines. (Newswires)

Other News - China announced plan to remove QFII and RQFII quota limits to further open its financial markets. (Newswires)

Trade

China Premier Li said US and China should find a solution to the trade dispute and hopes that talks make progress. (Newswires)

China is ready to sweeten deal by buying American goods in countdown to trade war talks according to a source, although reports added even a simple purchase agreement is no certainty and that purchasing of US goods would be in exchange for a delay on tariffs and easing of restrictions on Huawei. Furthermore, China could offer more market access and better IP protection as well as cutting industrial capacity, but would be reluctant to compromise on subsidies, industrial policies and reform of SOEs. (SCMP)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said it is a grave concern for US President Trump's administration that the Chinese did not live up to its commitments to purchase US agricultural goods and that this matter will be addressed in upcoming talks. (NY Times)

US Commerce Department's preliminary findings showed that imports of ceramic tiles from China have been subsidized unfairly and therefore have put preliminary duties of 103.77-222.24% on Chinese ceramic tile imports. (Newswires)

Renmin University of China’s Jin Canrong suggested that the US must concede the final 20% of demands to end trade war with China as the sides had agreed 80% of the deal as far back as May. (Newswires)
